1.text: Behold my eye hath seen all these things, and my ear hath heard them, and I have understood them all.

2.text: According to your knowledge I also know: neither am I inferior to you.

3.text: But yet I will speak to the Almighty, and I desire to reason with God.

4.text: Having first shewn that you are forgers of lies, and maintainers of perverse opinions.

5.text: And I wish you would hold your peace, that you might be thought to be wise men..

6.text: Hear ye therefore my reproof, and attend to the judgment of my lips.

7.text: Hath God any need of your lie, that you should speak deceitfully for him?

8.text: Do you accept his person, and do you endeavour to judge for God?

9.text: Or shall it please him, from whom nothing can be concealed ? or shall he be deceived as a man, with your deceitful dealings ?

10.text: He shall reprove you, because in secret you accept his person.

11.text: As soon as he shall move himself, he shall trouble you: and his dread shall fall upon you.

12.text: Your remembrance shall be compared to ashes, and your necks shall be brought to clay.

13.text: Hold your peace a little while, that I may speak whatsoever my mind shall suggest to me.

14.text: Why do I tear my flesh with my teeth, and carry my soul in my hands?

15.text: Although he should bill me, I will trust in him: but yet I will reprove my ways in his sight.

16.text: And he shall be my saviour: for no hypocrite shall come before his presence.

17.text: Hear ye my speech, and receive with Sour ears hidden truths.

18.text: If I shall be judged, I know that I shall be found just.

19.text: Who is he that will plead against me? let him come: why am I consumed holding my peace?

20.text: Two things only do not to me, and then from thy face I shall not be hid:

21.text: Withdraw thy hand far from me, and let not thy dread terrify me.

22.text: Call me, and I will answer thee: or else I will speak, and do thou answer me.

23.text: How many are my iniquities and sins? make me know my crimes and offences.

24.text: Why hidest thou thy face, and thinkest me thy enemy?

25.text: Against a leaf, that is carried away with the wind, thou shewest thy power, and thou pursuest a dry straw.

26.text: For thou writest bitter things against me, and wilt consume me for the sins of my youth.

27.text: Thou hast put my feet in the stocks, and hast observed all my paths, and hast considered the steps of my feet:

28.text: Who am to be consumed as rottenness, and as a garment that is moth-eaten.
